issues.description: Interface name mismatch: the problem statement and UML refer to an interface named `Rideable` (with method messageOnRide()), and the template Main.java also uses `Rideable`. However, the solution repository implements this concept under the name `Mountable` (Mountable.java, and Pig/Seal implement Mountable) while the solution's Rideable.java is empty. This naming inconsistency between `Rideable` and `Mountable` is structural (not just a missing method body) and will confuse students which interface to create/implement and may cause code/tests that expect `Rideable` to fail to compile or run.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the interface name consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) rename Mountable.java and any implementations (Pig, Seal) to Rideable and ensure the interface declares String messageOnRide(); and remove the empty Rideable.java, or (B) update the problem statement and template to use Mountable everywhere instead of Rideable. Prefer option (A) to match the UML and template wording (Rideable).

issues.description: The problem statement and template refer to an interface named 'Rideable' (the UML and the template Main use Rideable), but the solution implementation introduces an interface named 'Mountable' which Pig and Seal implement. The solution also contains an empty Rideable.java file. This renaming of the same conceptual interface (animals that can be ridden) across artifacts breaks the one-to-one mapping students expect from the UML/problem to the code and will cause confusion when students look for/implement the Rideable interface.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the interface name across all artifacts. Preferred fix: rename the solution's 'Mountable' interface to 'Rideable' (i.e., replace Mountable.java with Rideable.java) and update Pig.java and Seal.java to implement Rideable. Alternatively, if Mountable is intended, update the problem statement and template to use 'Mountable' everywhere. Also remove or populate the empty Rideable.java in the solution to avoid ambiguity.
